<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

A delivery company suggests using a remote-controlled aircraft to drop a parcel into the garden of a customer. The path of the parcel is shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 887, 323]]<|/det|>
The wavelength of light from a laser is determined using the apparatus shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 332, 814, 540]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 552, 591, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 584, 764, 602]]<|/det|>
The light from the laser is incident normally on the plane of the double slit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 599, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
The separation of the two slits is \(3.7 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}\). The screen is parallel to the plane of the double slit. The distance between the screen and the double slit is \(2.3 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 920, 677]]<|/det|>
A pattern of bright fringes and dark fringes is seen on the screen. The separation of adjacent bright fringes on the screen is \(4.3 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 692, 183, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 692, 561, 710]]<|/det|>
Calculate the wavelength, in nm, of the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 920, 920, 938]]<|/det|>
<form>wavelength = .................................................... nm [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the light passing through each slit was initially the same. The intensity of the light through one of the slits is now reduced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 851, 135]]<|/det|>
Compare the appearance of the fringes before and after the change of intensity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 252, 920, 271]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 274, 920, 292]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Metal wire is used to connect a power supply to a lamp. The wire has a total resistance of \(3.4 \Omega\) and the metal has a resistivity of \(2.6 \times 10^{- 8} \Omega \text{m}\). The total length of the wire is \(59 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 116, 712, 137]]<|/det|>
Show that the wire has a cross-sectional area of \(4.5 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 268, 920, 287]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 299, 181, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 298, 705, 318]]<|/det|>
The potential difference across the total length of wire is \(1.8 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 330, 463, 349]]<|/det|>
Calculate the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 428, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
<form>current = .................................................... A [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 460, 180, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 459, 759, 479]]<|/det|>
The number density of the free electrons in the wire is \(6.1 \times 10^{28} \text{m}^{- 3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 491, 734, 510]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average drift speed of the free electrons in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 675, 920, 696]]<|/det|>
<form>average drift speed = ............................................ $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 707, 131, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 707, 920, 742]]<|/det|>
A different wire carries a current. This wire has a part that is thinner than the rest of the wire, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 749, 761, 833]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 854, 532, 873]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 181, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
State and explain qualitatively how the average drift speed of the free electrons in the thinner part compares with that in the rest of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 179, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 181, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 209, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the power dissipated in the thinner part is the same, less or more than the power dissipated in an equal length of the rest of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 319, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 146, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 350, 630, 368]]<|/det|>
Three resistors have resistances of \(180\Omega , 90\Omega\) and \(30\Omega .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 181, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 381, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
Sketch a diagram showing how two of these three resistors may be connected together to give a combined resistance of \(60\Omega\) between the terminals shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 412, 714, 429]]<|/det|>
Ensure you label the values of the resistances in your diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 553, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 584, 181, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 584, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
A potential divider circuit is produced by connecting the three resistors to a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(12\mathrm{V}\) and negligible internal resistance. The potential divider circuit provides an output potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) of \(8.0\mathrm{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 630, 479, 648]]<|/det|>
Fig. 5.2 shows the circuit diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 655, 719, 826]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 873, 779, 907]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.2, label the resistances of all three resistors and the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 891, 920, 909]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 922, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[824, 945, 920, 961]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Two horizontal metal plates are separated by a distance of \(2.0 \text{cm}\) in a vacuum, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 121, 737, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 339, 532, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 371, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
The top plate has an electric potential of \(+180 \text{V}\) and the bottom plate has an electric potential of \(-120 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 181, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 418, 798, 437]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the electric field strength between the plates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 567, 920, 587]]<|/det|>
<form>electric field strength = ............................................. $NC^{-1}$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 599, 180, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 599, 507, 617]]<|/det|>
State the direction of the electric field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 630, 920, 648]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 661, 146, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
An uncharged atom of uranium-238 ( \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm {U})\) has a change made to its number of orbital electrons. This causes the atom to change into a new particle (ion) X that has an overall charge of \(+2e,\) where e is the elementary charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 723, 181, 741]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 723, 848, 742]]<|/det|>
Determine the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in the particle (ion) X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 821, 917, 840]]<|/det|>
<form>number of protons = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 853, 917, 871]]<|/det|>
<form>number of neutrons = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 884, 917, 902]]<|/det|>
<form>number of electrons = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 900, 920, 917]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 890, 89]]<|/det|>
The particle (ion) X is in the electric field in **(a)** at a point midway between the plates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 670, 120]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the electric force acting on X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 255, 920, 274]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 287, 180, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 286, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
The nucleus of uranium-238 ( \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm{U})\) decays in stages, by emitting \(\alpha\) -particles and \(\beta^{- }\) particles, to form a nucleus of thorium-230 ( \(^{230}_{90}\mathrm{Th})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 333, 920, 367]]<|/det|>
Calculate the total number of \(\alpha\) -particles and the total number of \(\beta^{- }\) particles that are emitted during the decay of uranium-238 to thorium-230.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 472, 917, 490]]<|/det|>
<form>number of \(\alpha\)-particles = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[383, 503, 920, 521]]<|/det|>
<form>number of \(\beta^{- }\) particles = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 521, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
